data: Primary Source Set - Franklin Pierce Listen Franklin Pierce was the 14th President of the United States, serving from 1853 to 1857. He was the only president to come from New Hampshire. He was born and raised in Hillsborough and later moved to Concord. Background Before he became president, Pierce was actively involved in his community, first as a lawyer and then as a politician. He served in the New Hampshire House of Representatives, the U.S. House of Representatives, and the U.S. Senate. Pierce dominated the Democratic Party in New Hampshire during the 1830s and 1840s, when Democrats controlled the state’s political affairs. He also became an influential figure in the Democratic Party nationally. Throughout his career, Pierce believed ardently that the federal union between the states must be preserved at all costs. Although he was personally opposed to slavery, he argued that slavery was protected in the U.S. Constitution and therefore the federal government must support it. In the 1830s, many political leaders shared this view, but public opinion began to shift in the 1840s, making Pierce’s position less popular among his northern colleagues. However, many still viewed him as a compromise between northern interests and those of the southern states—he was, after all, a northerner who was sympathetic to the South. He was a dark horse candidate for the presidency in 1852, but when the Democrats could not settle on another nominee, Pierce became their man on the 49th ballot. He won the general election with 51% of the popular vote and a strong majority in the electoral college. After becoming president, Pierce faced a number of insurmountable problems as sectional tensions threatened to rip the country apart. Even the members of his own cabinet did not get along. In an effort to please everyone, Pierce ended up pleasing no one. In 1854, he signed into law the Kansas-Nebraska Act, which allowed people living in the Kansas and Nebraska territories to vote on whether their states would allow slavery. The act overturned the 1820 Missouri Compromise that had essentially divided the country in half between slave and free states. The Kansas-Nebraska Act reopened this question and ushered in a period of violence in Kansas between the slave and free factions. The territory became known as “Bleeding Kansas,” and the fighting that occurred there would foreshadow the events of the Civil War (1861–65). As president, Pierce supported the slave faction in Kansas, which infuriated his northern supporters. He also backed several other failed or controversial proposals during his four years in office, although the Kansas-Nebraska Act is considered his most significant failure. As tumultuous as Pierce’s presidency had been, his personal life too was not without tragedy. None of his children survived childhood, and the last, his 11-year-old son Benny, died in a train accident just two months before Pierce took office. Pierce’s wife, Jane, never recovered from the loss and struggled to act as Pierce’s official hostess during his term in the White House. The couple became close with Pierce’s secretary of war, Jefferson Davis, and his wife Varina. (Davis would later become the president of the Confederacy during the Civil War.) By the time Pierce left the U.S. presidency in 1857, he could claim that he had helped America expand farther westward, but he had only made worse the sectional tension regarding slavery. Pierce’s party turned against him, and he was not nominated by the Democrats for re-election to the presidency at the end of his term. He returned to Concord in 1857 and continued to publicly argue that the preservation of the Union was more important than the abolition of slavery. Although he still had some supporters, many objected to Pierce’s position, and after Pierce’s death in 1869, there was a fair amount of controversy over how he should be commemorated in New Hampshire. A statue was not erected to him on the state house lawn until 1914. This primary source set guide can be used in several ways to explore the life of Franklin Pierce. It is not necessary to use all sources in a set to create a meaningful inquiry. Rather, educators are encouraged to select—or have their students select—the sources best suited to your project. Additional Resources Elizabeth Dubrulle, “Franklin Pierce: ‘Great Statesman’ or ‘Traitor to the Country’?” Historical New Hampshire 72 (Spring 2019): 82–93, which includes a discussion of the controversy over Pierce’s state house statue. Focus Questions In addition to our general suggestions for using primary source sets, consider giving students one of the following prompts for an inquiry using this primary source set about Franklin Pierce. 1 What can you tell about Franklin Pierce given these sources? 2 How should Franklin Pierce be celebrated if he was a famous Granite Stater but also caused a lot of disagreements because of his actions as president? Listen Video Mason Asks: Who Was Franklin Pierce? Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Mason Asks: Who Was Franklin Pierce? America's 14th President Only one United States president has come from New Hampshire: Franklin Pierce! Franklin Pierce was elected president during a very difficult time in our country’s history. Watch to learn more about what Franklin Pierce was like and how he is remembered by people in New Hampshire. Click On An Icon To Find A Resource! Biographies Documents Maps & Charts Objects Photographs & Prints Biographies in this Primary Source Set: Franklin Pierce Listen Biography Franklin Pierce 1804–1869 Caption: Franklin Pierce was the 19th president of the United States and the only president from New Hampshire. He was born and raised in Hillsborough, New Hampshire, and later moved to Concord. He was a lawyer and a politician. Before he was elected president, he represented New Hampshire in the U.S. Congress. He also served in the U.S. Army in the Mexican-American War. He was president for one term, from 1853 to 1857. This was a very difficult time for the United States. There was a lot of tension between the North and the South over slavery. President Pierce thought it was more important to keep the country together than to abolish slavery. He tried to find a compromise between the two sides, but it did not work and made the problems worse. Image Credit: Portrait by Adna Tenney, 1852, New Hampshire Historical Society Documents in this Primary Source Set: Jefferson Davis Letter to Franklin Pierce Listen Document Jefferson Davis Letter to Franklin Pierce 1861 Jefferson Davis Caption: Jefferson Davis was a politician from Mississippi. He and his wife became friends with Franklin and Jane Pierce when they all lived in Washington, D.C., when Pierce and Davis were in the U.S. Congress. When Pierce became president of the United States in 1853, he asked Davis to join his government as the secretary of war. Pierce only served one term as president, and then returned to New Hampshire. He and Davis kept in touch. As the country became more and more divided, southern states started seceding from, or leaving, the United States. Davis wrote this letter to Pierce right after Mississippi seceded from the United States. One month later, Davis became president of the Confederate States of America. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce Celebration Dinner Menu Listen Document Pierce Celebration Dinner Menu 1852 New Hampshire Steam Printing Works Caption: Franklin Pierce was the only person from New Hampshire to be elected president of the United States. When he won the election in November 1852, many people in New Hampshire celebrated. In December, a big dinner was held in his honor at the Eagle Hotel in Concord, across from the State House. This menu was given to guests at the dinner to bring home as a keepsake or memory. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce's Inaugural Address Listen Document Pierce's Inaugural Address 1853 Printed by John Murphy Company Caption: American presidents are elected every four years in November, but they are inaugurated—officially take office—a few months later. They have to swear an oath that they will follow the Constitution. Today, presidents are inaugurated in January, but before the 1930s, inaugurations were in March. Since the time of George Washington, presidents have given a speech after they take the oath of office. The speech, called an inaugural address, usually describes their plans for their presidency. This document is a printing of Franklin Pierce's inaugural address. People could buy it as a keepsake or memory of the time. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Turbulent Scenes Mark Pierce Statue Debate Listen Document Turbulent Scenes Mark Pierce Statue Debate 1911 Manchester Daily Mirror and American Caption: This article describes the debate in the New Hampshire House of Representatives about whether the state should pay for a statue of Franklin Pierce to be built and placed in front of the State House. The article appeared in a Manchester, New Hampshire, newspaper on February 23, 1911. It describes how controversial the issue was. Both sides were very passionate and representatives were booing and hissing each other during the debate. Image Credit: From the collections of the New Hampshire State Library Maps & Charts in this Primary Source Set: Free States and Slave States Listen Maps & Charts Free States and Slave States Caption: During the 1800s, the United States expanded west from the 13 original colonies into a much larger nation. Before the Civil War, whenever a new territory or state joined the United States, there was a big debate over whether slavery would be allowed there. In 1820, it was decided that there would be no more slavery north of the southern border of Missouri. In 1850, it was decided that the people who lived in the New Mexico territory and Utah territory should be allowed to vote on whether they would have slavery, even though some of that land was north of the 1820 line. In 1854, when Franklin Pierce was president of the United States, he signed a law called the Kansas-Nebraska Act. This allowed people who lived in the Kansas and Nebraska territories to vote on whether they would have slavery. This expansion of slavery into new parts of the United States angered people who were opposed to slavery, and helped set the stage for the Civil War. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Objects in this Primary Source Set: Franklin Pierce Statue Listen Objects Franklin Pierce Statue 1914 August Lukeman Caption: After Franklin Pierce died in 1869, many Granite Staters thought he deserved to have a statue at the State House. Pierce had been a popular politician with many friends. Not only had he represented New Hampshire in the U.S. Congress, he was the only person from New Hampshire to be elected president of the United States. Other people disagreed and felt that he had made too many mistakes as president. Finally in 1914 this statue of Franklin Pierce was placed at the front corner of the State House lawn. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Franklin Pierce Statue in Concord Listen Objects Franklin Pierce Statue in Concord Photo by Carol M. Highsmith Caption: After Franklin Pierce died in 1869, many Granite Staters thought he deserved to have a statue in front of the State House. He was the only person from New Hampshire to have been elected president of the United States. Other people disagreed and felt he had made too many mistakes as president. In 1914 this statue, designed by August Lukeman, was placed at the front corner of the State House lawn. Image Credit: Photographs in Carol M. Highsmith's America Project in the Carol M. Highsmith Archive, Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division Kansas-Nebraska Act Pen Listen Objects Kansas-Nebraska Act Pen 1854 Caption: When Franklin Pierce was president of the United States, he used this pen to sign a law called the Kansas-Nebraska Act in 1854. During this time, the United States was expanding into the west, and a lot of new states were joining the country. Before the Kansas-Nebraska Act, new states in the north did not have slavery, and new states in the south did have slavery. The new law allowed new states to choose whether they would permit slavery or not. This angered people who were opposed to slavery, and helped set the stage for the Civil War. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce Campaign Ribbon Listen Objects Pierce Campaign Ribbon 1852 Caption: This campaign ribbon for Franklin Pierce was worn by his supporters when Pierce was running for president in 1852. Just like campaign buttons or pins today, ribbons like this one were worn by people who wanted to show their support for a specific candidate. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce Law Office Sign Listen Objects Pierce Law Office Sign circa 1842 Caption: Franklin Pierce was a lawyer in Concord during the 1840s, before he became the U.S. president, and this sign hung at his office. Pierce was known for being an excellent public speaker, and people came from all over the state to hear him argue his cases in the courtroom. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce's Mexican-American War Sword Listen Objects Pierce's Mexican-American War Sword 1849 Ames Manufacturing Company Caption: The state of New Hampshire gave this sword to Franklin Pierce in 1849 to thank him for serving in the U.S. Army in the Mexican-American War. The war was fought between Mexico and the United States from 1846 to 1848 over whether Texas should become a U.S. state. Pierce was a brigadier general who commanded over 2,000 men and fought in several battles in Mexico. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Photographs & Prints in this Primary Source Set: Franklin Pierce Listen Photograph/Print Franklin Pierce circa 1853 Ulysses D. Tenney Caption: This is a portrait of Franklin Pierce, the only person from New Hampshire to ever become president of the United States. He was born in Hillsborough in 1804 and later moved to Concord. Pierce was a lawyer and a politician, and represented New Hampshire in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate. He also served in the U.S. Army in the Mexican-American War. He was elected president in 1852 and served one term, from 1853 to 1857. He died in 1869. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Franklin Pierce, 1861 Listen Photograph/Print Franklin Pierce, 1861 1861 Caption: Franklin Pierce was president of the United States from 1853 to 1857. Then he returned to Concord, but he was not very popular in New Hampshire. Many northerners were angry that he had sided with southerners about allowing slavery in Kansas. When the Civil War began, he was even less popular. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Jane Means Appleton Pierce Listen Photograph/Print Jane Means Appleton Pierce 1853 John Adams Whipple Caption: Jane Means Appleton married lawyer and politician Franklin Pierce in 1834. She did not like the world of politics and preferred to live in New Hampshire instead of Washington, D.C. When she found out that her husband was nominated to be a candidate for president of the United States in 1852, she fainted. The Pierces had three children, but they all died at young ages. Their third child, Benny, was killed in a terrible train accident right before Franklin Pierce became president. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce Campaign Poster Listen Photograph/Print Pierce Campaign Poster 1852 Nathaniel Currier Caption: This campaign poster from the election of 1852 shows candidates Franklin Pierce for president and William King for vice-president. Pierce was a dark horse, or unexpected, candidate. The Democratic Party chose him because he did not take a firm position either for or against slavery, and they thought he had the best chance to win. Pierce did win the election, and became the only person from New Hampshire to be president of the United States. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce Leaving Concord Listen Photograph/Print Pierce Leaving Concord 1853 Caption: Franklin Pierce was elected president of the United States in November 1852. This engraving shows Pierce leaving Concord for Washington, D.C. It was printed in a newspaper called Frank Leslie's Illustrated News in February 1853. Before the 1930s, presidents used to take their oath of office in March. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society Pierce Presidential Campaign Photograph Listen Photograph/Print Pierce Presidential Campaign Photograph 1852 William Hazen Kimball Caption: New Hampshire politician Franklin Pierce ran for president of the United States in the election of 1852. He used this photograph in his campaign. There were no movies, television, or internet, so photographs were the only way voters would know what he looked like. Pierce is wearing his military uniform in the photograph. He served in the U.S. Army during the Mexican-American War in the 1840s. Image Credit: New Hampshire Historical Society
